Indiaâ€™s foreign ministry has said that the mural depicts the spread of the Ashokan empire and the idea of responsible and people-oriented governance that he adopted and propagated. â€œThat is what the mural and the plaque in front of the mural says,â€ Indian foreign ministry spokesperson Arindam Bagchi had said.Last week, several political leaders in Nepal, including the countryâ€™s prime minister had objected to the mural as it shows Lumbini â€“ the birthplace of the founder of Buddhism Gautama Buddha â€“ as part of it. Nepal considers Lumbini as one of the major cultural centres on its map. The foreign ministry of Pakistan has also objected to the mural.On Monday, Bangladeshi minister Alam took cognisance of Bagchiâ€™s clarification, saying that the mural depicts the journey of people. â€œThere may be cultural similarities, but it has nothing to do with politics,â€ he had said.In Bangladesh, resentment has been simmering over the mural since last week as several political parties â€“ besides the ruling Awami League â€“ had criticised their country being included in the mural, according to the newspaper Prothom Alo. Jatiyo Samajtantrik Dal, an ally of the ruling Awami League, said that there was no such thing as â€œAkhand Bharatâ€ in the political map of India after 1947. â€œThe display of a map of undivided India in Indiaâ€™s parliament building is unwarranted,â€ the partyâ€™s president Hasanul Huq Inu told Prothom Alo.Mirza Fakhrul Islam Alamgir, the secretary-general of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, said that displaying Bangladesh as part of the undivided map of any other nation was a threat to his countryâ€™s independence and sovereignty.The Rastra Sangskar Andolan said in a statement said: â€œIt is objectionable for Bangladesh to be included as part of Akhand Bharat in the imagined map of the Indian rulers.â€
